item.title: Scopely acquires majority stake in Pixel Flow! developer Loom Games
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 19, 2026

1 Min Read

Saudi-owned publisher Scopely has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Pixel Flow! developer Loom Games for an undisclosed fee. 

Although financial terms were not disclosed, Scopely said the move values Loom Games in excess of $1 billion. 

Pixel Flow! was released by the Istanbul-based studio in late 2025 and has attracted over 10 million players while also breaking into the top-20 grossing charts in the United States. 

Scopely chief revenue officer Tim O'Brien said Pixel Flow! has demonstrated the 'rare and impressive' ability to immediately engage players and praised the creativity of its 20-person development team. 

"We are constantly exploring opportunities that could bring more world-class teams and game franchises into our operating system, and this investment signals our ongoing commitment to being a leading partner in the space," he added. 

"We look forward to welcoming the Pixel Flow! team into the Scopely ecosystem and supporting their exciting roadmap ahead." 

Related:Report: Tencent was Highguard's secret financial backer

Loom Games co-founder Kübra Gündoğan said Scopely shares her confidence in the hybrid-casual market and explained the deal will deliver vital support without compromising the studio's independence. 

"[Scopely's] unique ecosystem will allow us to maintain our creative autonomy while also learning from each other and continuing to build games that can become a meaningful part of players' lives for the long term," she added. 

Gündoğan will continue to lead Loom Games with fellow co-founder Emre Çelik. 

Scopely—which last year acquired Pokemon Go and Niantic's wider game business, and is currently owned by Saudi state-backed investment vehicle Savvy Games Group—noted the deal will also expand its footprint in the EMEA region.

item.title: Report: Tencent was Highguard's secret financial backer
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello,

Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 19, 2026

1 Min Read

Image via Wildlight Entertainment

Chinese conglomerate Tencent was reportedly the lead financial backer behind Wildlight Entertainment's hero shooter Highguard.

Anonymous sources familiar with the matter told Game File the title was largely financed by Tencent subsidiary TiMi Studio Group—known for working on titles like Pokémon: Unite and Call of Duty: Mobile.

It’s worth noting that neither company has confirmed the report. Over on LinkedIn, as spotted by IGN, the official page for Wildlight Entertainment has long included the line that it is "a new, fully-funded entertainment studio."

Speaking to Bloomberg last month, Wildlight CEO Dusty Welch declined to disclose the source of that funding. "We don’t really speak publicly about the business, and the economics and the financials of our company," said Welch. 

Welch previously told The Game Business that Wildlight was an independent entity operating without the "support of a big organization."

Related:Payday 2 was outperforming Payday 3 towards the end of 2025

Wildlight was founded at the end of 2021, with a team comprised of several ex-Respawn Entertainment developers. The studio launched Highguard as a free-to-play title on January 26, 2026. Despite initially attracting a large number of players, it appears Highguard failed to meet internal expectations.

Just two weeks after the shooter debuted, Wildlight laid off all but a "core group" of developers who will continue to work on Highguard. "Today we made an incredibly difficult decision to part ways with a number of our team members while keeping a core group of developers to continue innovating on and supporting the game," explained the studio in a statement. "We're proud of the team, talent, and the product we've created together."

item.title: Payday 2 was outperforming Payday 3 towards the end of 2025
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr,

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 19, 2026

3 Min Read

Starbreeze has struggled to make headway with Payday 3 since it launched in September 2023, with the title almost immediately falling short of expectations—prompting the Swedish publisher to form a "strike team of veteran developers" to rehabilitate the title. 

Starbreeze, however, remains adamant the threequel is showing "clear potential." That's despite it being outperformed by Payday 2 during the fourth quarter of the fiscal year. 

As noted in the company's latest fiscal report, Payday 2 delivered net sales of SEK 14.8 million ($1.6 million) during the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2025. By contrast, Payday 3 delivered net sales of SEK 8 million ($880,000).

Full-year net sales for Payday 2 totalled SEK 50.1 million across the 2025 fiscal year, while Payday 3 delivered net sales of SEK 76.5 million over the same period. 

Although Payday 3 generated more sales over the entire year, that total represents a downturn on its performances in 2024 and 2023. For instance, the title generated full-year net sales of SEK 82.9 million and SEK 477 million in 2024 and 2023, respectively. 

Related:Brazilian studio Devcats ventures into publishing

Those numbers highlight the magnitude of the task currently facing Starbreeze, with Payday 3 net sales having plummeted post-launch. 

Starbreeze said it was focused on stabilizing its business during the last fiscal year, leading to consolidated net sales of SEK 221 million—an increase on the SEK 185.9 million it reported the year prior. 

"Strengthening trust with players and the community is a long-term effort"

Starbreeze CEO Adolf Kristjansson—who was appointed in March 2025 to change the company's fortunes—explained the Payday 3 team has now established a stable monthly cadence for updates, which he described as a "key milestone in our transition toward a more consistent live-engagement model."

"The release of Skills 2.0 marked a meaningful step forward, directly addressing long-standing player feedback and enabling deeper, more impactful build customization. This work will continue, with ongoing tuning and improvements based on both player input and our long-term vision for the game," he added. 

"Shortly after year-end, we launched the Shopping Spree Heist, introducing new gameplay scenarios with a strong focus on replayability, alongside additional quality-of-life improvements. Together, these releases represent tangible progress in improving the Payday 3 experience. Strengthening trust with players and the community is a long-term effort, and the team remains focused on consistent delivery."

Related:Mewgenics has sold 1 million copies worldwide

Kristjansson said Payday 2 exceeded expectations over the seasonal sales period and is being supported with both updates and new content via an exclusive partnership with an external development team. That partnership has purportedly allowed Starbreeze's internal teams to focus entirely on Payday 3.

Discussing the company's internal structure, Kristjansson said Starbreeze has taken "deliberate steps" to simplify and align operations—presumably referring to the layoffs made by the studio last year—and noted those changes have "enabled clearer decision-making, improved accountability, and stronger cross-functional collaboration."

He also indicated the company is rethinking its work-for-hire model. 

"As we continue to sharpen focus while maintaining our cash discipline, we have taken steps after the quarter to adapt our cost base, primarily in Special Operations, our work-for-hire segment," he added. "While work- for-hire is a viable part of our business when the right opportunities arise, these adjustments ensure that our organization is aligned with demand and supports our long-term ambition to build a simpler, more predictable, and financially resilient company."

Starbreeze had 143 employees as of December 31, 2025. The company previously had 189 workers on its books at the end of 2024.
